description: Created by Logical Operations, the CyberSec First Responder certification, which is DoD Directive 8570 compliant, will prepare security professionals to become the first responders in their organization. You will learn how to defend against cyber-attacks, analyze threats, design secure computing and network environments, proactively defend networks, and respond/investigate to cybersecurity incidents.
descriptionMD: Created by [Logical Operations](http://logicaloperations.com/itprotv-cfr/), the CyberSec First Responder certification, which is DoD Directive 8570 compliant, will prepare security professionals to become the first responders in their organization. You will learn how to defend against cyber-attacks, analyze threats, design secure computing and network environments, proactively defend networks, and respond/investigate to cybersecurity incidents.
name: CyberSec First Responder
subtitle: Logical Operations

episodes.description: The CyberSec First Responder program will prepare security professionals to become the first responders in their organization. You will learn how to defend against cyber-attacks analyze threats, design secure computing and network environments, proactively defend networks, and respond/investigate cybersecurity incidents.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike start the series by building a foundation of knowledge about specific threats called Threat Profiles. They begin by discussing and defining Threat Actors, which includes Insiders, Script Kiddies, Hackers, and Cyber Criminals.
episodes.title: Threat Profiles

episodes.description: In this	episode, Daniel	and Mike continue their explanation about different Threat Actors, specifically defining Hacktivists, State Sponsored Hackers, and Cyberterrorists. Then they discuss and define Threat Motives and Threat Intent which includes, the desire for money/power/recognition, revenge, and blackmail.
episodes.title: Threat Profiles Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish exploring the different Threat Motives as well as discussing Attack Vectors and Technique Criteria. The Attack Vectors discussed includes Vulnerabilites, Exploits, and Techniques used while the Technique Criteria involves direct vs. indirect, stealth/non-stealth, and client-side/server-side.
episodes.title: Threat Profiles Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike begin their discussion on the Tools and Techniques used by the Threat Actors to gather information about target networks and/or devices. They start their conversation by explaining the crucial information gathering methods used when Footprinting a target. This includes DNS info gathering, Dumpster Diving, Social Media searching, and even Google searching.
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on the Tools and Techniques used by the Threat Actors to gather information about target networks and/or devices. Here they explore Port Scanning, Vulnerability Scanning, and Network Scanning using tools like Nmap. Also covered is system/user Enumeration.
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on the Tools and Techniques used by the Threat Actors to gather information about target networks and/or devices. Here they pick up by demonstrating the use of the Nmap network scanning utility. They will show you how to look for live hosts, scan those hosts for running services, as well as version and Operating
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their look at the techniques and tools used by CyberSec First Responders. Here they demonstrate and explain the use of Protocol analyzers, aka Packet Sniffers, specifically they will demo one of the most popular sniffers called Wireshark.
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their look at the techniques and tools used by CyberSec First Responders. This time around they will be demonstrating and explaining how to scan your environment for vulnerabilities using the Nessus vunerability scanner.
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss password attacks commonly used by both Security Admin and Threat Actor. They begin with password sniffing, which exploys the use of a protocol analyzer/packet sniffer to capture passwords from network packets. Then they explore password cracking through Brute Force, Dictionary, Guessing, and Rainbow Tables.
episodes.title: Password Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate the use of Ncrack, a popular password cracking utility, to perform a dictionary attack against an SSH server.
episodes.title: Password Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the world of Exploit Frameworks. They begin by discussing the different Frameworks that you may encounter as a First Responder, including Metasploit, Core Impact, and CANVAS. Then then perform a demonstration of compromising a vulnerable system using Metasploit.
episodes.title: Gaining Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the common web attacks that are used by Threat Actors against web servers and clients. They begin by explaining Cross-Site Scripting(XSS) and Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks. Then they discuss the components of a SQL Injection attack. Finally, they finish by exploring Directory Traversal and Local/Remote File Inclusion (LFI/RFI) attacks.
episodes.title: Web Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue exploring the common web attacks that are used by Threat Actors against web servers and clients. Here they walk you through a demonstration of a typical SQL Injection attack against a web server.
episodes.title: Web Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the concept of Malware. Here they carefully define what Malware is as well as explore the many different types of Malware that you may encounter. Finally, they discuss the methods of avoidance and remediation using Anti-Virus systems.
episodes.title: Malware

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike jump into the fascinating world of Man-in-the-Middle attacks. They begin by defining what Man-in-the-Middle(MitM) attacks are and then further explore the different types of MitMs that you may encounter. This includes ARP Spoofing, DHCP Spoofing, Session Hijacking, and DNS Poisoning.
episodes.title: Man in the Middle Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate the process of performing a Man-in-the-Middle attack. Here they take you step-by-step through the use of Ettercap to initiate an ARP Cache Poisoning technique which will facilitate the MitM attack.
episodes.title: Man in the Middle Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike, discuss wireless centric attacks as well as concepts surrounding denial-of-services attack or DoS. They will look at various topics such as wireless cracking, wireless client attacks, infrastructure attacks as well as various types of DoS-based attacks
episodes.title: Wireless and DoS Attacks

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike talk about various data sources in cyber security. They discuss security intelligence, cyber security management, what to monitor, data collection and general guidelines
episodes.title: Data Sources

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on various data sources in cyber security. They look at information processing, external data sources, publicly available information, collection and report automation and data retention.
episodes.title: Data Sources Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on various data sources in cyber security. They look at firewall logs, IPS and IDS logs, web application firewall logs, carrier logs, network sniffers, operating system and vulnerability testing data
episodes.title: Data Sources Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike dive into log analysis and which tools to use for the analysis. They demonstrate Linux utilities like grep, cut and diff.
episodes.title: Log Analysis

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration into log analysis and which tools to use for the analysis. They will look at Windows tools like Find, the Windows Management Instrumentation Client, Event Viewer and finally they will talk about scripting languages and log correlation.
episodes.title: Log Analysis Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration into log analysis and which tools to use for the analysis. They will take a look at a couple of scripting languages such as the UNIX-based Bash and  Windows-based Powershell.
episodes.title: Log Analysis Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike show you how to use regular expression to parse log files and locate meaningful data. They begin by explaining the different search types and regular search operators, then moving on to special operators.
episodes.title: Regular Expressions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their look at regular expression. Here they take what you've learned so far and demonstrate their use.
episodes.title: Regular Expressions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish their look at regular expression. Here they take what you've learned so far and demonstrate their use.
episodes.title: Regular Expressions Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike show you some of the common tools used in the Windows OS to analyze security incidents. Here they will walk you through using tools like Regedit, Wireshark, netstat, nmap, SpaceSniffer, Tasklist, msconfig, and AD explorer.
episodes.title: Analyze Incidents with Windows

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike show you some of the common tools used in Linux operating systems to analyze security incidents. Here they will walk you through using tools like nmap, tcpdump, dd, htop, free, rwho, and lastlog.
episodes.title: Analyze Incidents with Linux

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike walk you through the common methods and tools used for malware analysis. They cover methods like sandboxing, employing virtualization to create a safe environment for testing. They also explore reverse engineering tools and other general tools including AntiVirus software and Malware Scanners.
episodes.title: Malware Analysis

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike look at the indications of a potential comprise within systems or networks. They talk about unauthorized programs, malicious software, registry modification, excessive bandwidth utilization, open ports, failed logons and more.
episodes.title: Potential Compromise Indicators

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the importance of best practices in preparation for incident response. Watch as they cover topics like preparation and planning, the need for ongoing training, communication methods, documentation, escalation procedures, and industry standards.
episodes.title: Best Practices

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explain the concepts surrounding an incident response process a business will take when an incident has be identified. They will talk about identification, containment, eradication, recovery, post incident as well as reporting and documentation.
episodes.title: Incident Response Process

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain general mitigation methods and devices. They start by looking at methods like system hardening, blocking known malware sources, and DNS filtering. They also discuss other methods like Blackhole Routing, System/App Isolation, Mobile Device Management
episodes.title: Mitigation Methods

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain general mitigation methods and devices. They jump back in by looking at specific devices and their specific roles. These devices include Firewalls, Switches, Routers, Proxies, Virtual Machines, Mobile platforms, Desktops, and Servers.
episodes.title: Mitigation Methods Part 2
